Award.AwardTitle: Hopf algebras, modular categories and their invariants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the structure of certain finite-dimensional Hopf algebras, their categories of representations, and spherical fusion categories. The main part of this project concerns some categorical arithmetic invariants such as dimensions, exponents, Frobenius-Schur indicators, and representations of the modular group associated with modular tensor categories. These arithmetic invariants are closely related among each other, and they serve as important tools for studying these algebraic structures. A basic question is the relationship between the prime factors of the dimension of a simple object and those of the quasi-exponent of the underlying category. Any progress here would help in proving a conjecture of Kaplansky on semisimple Hopf algebras that remains open. The project also concerns the classification of Hopf algebras whose dimensions admit a simple prime factorization. Progress on the preceding basic question would also help in classifying finite-dimensional Hopf algebras.

The appeal of symmetry has been guidance for understanding the nature of science. Some symmetry can be described in terms of algebraic structures. For instance, the symmetry of platonic solids can be described by some finite groups of spatial rotations. Hopf algebras and tensor categories are generalizations of groups which can also describe the symmetry of some physical systems. They appear naturally in many areas of mathematics and mathematical physics such as conformal field theory, statistical mechanics, and quantum computations. Thus, a deeper understanding of these algebraic structures is of fundamental importance and it will eventually be useful in the other areas of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The appeal of symmetry has been guidance for understanding the nature of science. Some symmetry can be described in terms of algebraic structures. Hopf algebras and tensor categories are generalizations of groups which can be used to describe the symmetry of some physical systems. They appear naturally in many areas of mathematics and mathematical physics such as conformal field theory, statistical mechanics, and quantum computations. This project studies the structure of Hopf algebras and invariants of tensor categories.

              During the entire period of the project, the PI has authored 11 articles; two of them submitted, two accepted and 7 published. All of these articles have been posted on the arXiv.

[1] Hopf algebras of prime dimension in positive characteristic (with Xingting Wang), arXiv:1810.00476.

[2] Nonsemisimple Hopf algebras of dimension 8p with the Chevalley property (with M. Beattie, G. A. Garcia and J. Roat), arXiv:1803.00271, to appear in Contemp. Math.

[3] Classification of super-modular categories by rank (with P. Bruillard , C. Galindo, J. Plavnik, E. Rowell and Z. Wang), arXiv:1705.05293.

[4] Generalized twisted quantum doubles of a finite group and rational orbifolds (with G. Mason), arXiv:1703.06489, to appear in Bulletin of the Institute of Mathematics Academia Sinica.

[5] Gauge invariants from the powers of antipodes (with C. Negron), arXiv:1609.00994, Pacific J. Math. 291 (2017), no. 2, 439-460.

[6] Fermionic Modular Categories and the 16-fold Way (with P. Bruillard , C. Galindo, T. Hagge, J. Plavnik E. Rowell and Z. Wang), J. Math. Phys. 58 (2017), no. 4, 041704.

[7] On Classification of Modular Categories by Rank (with P.Bruillard, E. Rowell and Z. Wang), Int. Math. Res. Not., IMRN 2016, no. 24, 7546-7588.

[8] Rank-finiteness for modular categories (with P. Bruillard, E. Rowell and Z. Wang), J. Amer. Math. Soc., 29 (2016), no.3, 857-881.

[9] On the Classification of Weakly Integral Modular Categories (with P. Bruillard, C. Galindo, J. Plavnik, E. Rowell and Z. Wang), J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 220 (2016), no.6, 2364-2388.

[10] Congruence property in conformal field theory (with C. Dong and X. Lin), Algebra Number Theory, 9 (2015), no. 9, 2121-2166.

[11] Cleft Extensions and Quotients of Twisted Quantum Doubles (with G. Mason), Developments in Mathematics, 34. Springer, New York, 2014, 229-246.

Intellectual Merits:

               In the past two decades, a lot progress has been made on finite-dimensional Hopf algebras. However, the understanding of Hopf algebras in small dimension remains limited. The articles [1] and [2] are devoted to classify "small" Hopf algebras. In [3], new arithmetic invariants were introduced for the tensor category of the representations of a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra.

               The articles [6], [7], [8], [9], [10] are the investigations of spherical fusion categories or modular tensor categories. Article [8] is one of the most significant outcomes of this project. It proves a Cauchy theorem and the rank-finiteness conjecture for modular categories. In the terminology of quantum computation, the theorem means that only finitely many quantum computers can be built from for a given number of anyons.

              Article [10] is another significant paper of this project. It proves the congruence character conjecture of rational vertex operator algebras, and the congruence property of lifted modular data conjectured by Coste-Gannon. Both [9] and [10] are fundamental to the theory modular categories. The articles [6], [7], [8] are applications of [9] and [10] for the classification of modular categories by ranks or dimensions.

               The articles [4] and [11] address the relations among orbifolds of vertex operator algebras, quasi-Hopf algebras and their tensor categories of representations. In particular, a new family of quasi-Hopf algebras is constructed, which is expected to describe the modular categories of rational orbifolds.

Boarder Impacts:

              The PI integrates research into his teaching. The PI?s PhD student, Jolie Roat, was supported by this project to work on the classification of Hopf algebras for her thesis. Part of her thesis was published in [2], and she is now an assistant professor at SUNY-Cortland. There were other junior mathematicians worked with the PI on this project such as Julia Plavnik ([3], [6], [9]) and Cris Negron ([2]). Both of them are hired as assistant professors at the Indiana University and the University of North Carolina respectively. Motivated by the project outcomes, the PI designed a graduate course on Hopf algebras and tensor categories at LSU, and he also gave a lecture series on arithmetic invariants of tensor categories at the Nanjing University.

              The PI has been actively organizing workshops and meetings for the community related to this project. He co-organized a BIRS workshop at Oaxaca in 2016, special sessions at the JMM of 2015, 2017 and 2018, AIM SQuaRE workshops in 2014, 2015 and 2016, and an AMS MRC in 2016. In addition, he also invited many junior researchers to LSU to give talks at the algebra seminar and to exchange ideas.
